introduction.p: If we consider different forcing functions g(t) for the equation x'' + px' + qx = g(t), functions that are periodic are especially important. Recall that a function g(t) is periodicperiodic function if g(t + T) = g(t) for all t and some fixed constant T. The most familiar periodic functions are g(t) = \sin \omega t \mbox{ and } g(t) = \cos \omega t. The periodperiod of a function for each of these two functions is 2 \pi / \omega and the frequencyfrequency is \omega / 2 \pi. These two functions share the additional property that their average value is zero. That is, \frac{1}{T} \int_0^T g(t) \, dt = 0. We say that sinusoidal forcingsinusoidal forcing occurs in the differential equation x'' + px' + qx = A \cos \omega t + B \sin \omega t.

subsection.title: Complexification
subsection.p: Given a second-order linear differential equation a x'' + bx' + cx = A \cos \omega t + B \sin \omega t, we can use Euler's formula, e^{i \beta t} = \cos \beta t + i \sin \beta t to derive a particular solution. That is, we will assume that our particular solution has the form x_c = x_\text{Re} + i x_\text{Im} and use the properties of complex numbers.If complex numbers make you uncomfortable, the alternative is to become an expert in trigonometric identities

example.p: Let us consider the equation x'' + 6 x' + 5x = \sin 2t. The solution to the corresponding homogeneous equation, x'' + 6 x' + 5x = 0, is x_h = c_1 e^{-5t} + c_2 e^{-t}. To find a particular solution, we can use the method of undetermined coefficients and assume that the solution has the form x_p = A \cos 2t + B \sin 2 t. If we carry out the appropriate calculations, we will obtain a particular solution x_p = - \frac{12}{145} \cos 2t + \frac{1}{145} \sin 2t. Thus, the general solution is x = x_h + x_p = c_1 e^{-5t} + c_2 e^{-t} - \frac{12}{145} \cos 2t + \frac{1}{145} \sin 2t. Notice that all solutions of will approach the particular solution as t \to \infty.

Now let us solve using complex numbers. If we assume that the equation has a complex solution of the form x_c = x_\text{Re} + i x_\text{Im}, then
\frac{d^2}{dt^2} x_c+ 6 \frac{d}{dt} x_c + 5 x_c & = \frac{d^2}{dt^2} (x_\text{Re} + i x_\text{Im}) + 6 \frac{d}{dt} (x_\text{Re} + i x_\text{Im}) + 5 (x_\text{Re} + i x_\text{Im}) & = e^{2it} & = \cos 2t + i \sin 2t.
Equating the real and imaginary parts of this equation, we obtain
x''_\text{Re} + 6 x'_\text{Re} + 5 x_\text{Re} & = \cos 2t x''_\text{Im} + 6 x'_\text{Im} + 5 x_\text{Im} & = \sin 2t.
Thus, if we can find a complex solution, we can find a solution to x'' + 6x' + 5x = \sin 2t simply by examining the imaginary part of the solution.

Now let us assume that our solution has the form x_c = A e^{2it}. Then
x_c''+ 6 x_c' + 5 x_c & = - 4 A e^{2it} + 12 A i e^{2it} + 5 A e^{2it} & = (1 + 12i) A e^{2it} & = (1 + 12i) A (\cos 2t + i \sin 2t).
Equating the real and imaginary parts of this equation, we obtain
x''_\text{Re} + 6 x'_\text{Re} + 5 x_\text{Re} & = \cos 2t x''_\text{Im} + 6 x'_\text{Im} + 5 x_\text{Im} & = \sin 2t
and we immediately see that A = \frac{1}{1 + 12i} = \frac{1}{145} - \frac{12}{145} i. Therefore, the complex solution to x'' + 6 x' + 5x = e^{2it} is
x_c & = A e^{2it} & = \left( \frac{1}{145} - \frac{12}{145} i\right) \cdot (\cos 2t + i \sin 2t) & = \left( \frac{1}{145} \cos 2t + \frac{12}{145} \sin 2t \right) + i \left( -\frac{12}{145} \cos 2t + \frac{1}{145} \sin 2t \right).
The imaginary part of this function is x_\text{Im} = -\frac{12}{145} \cos 2t + \frac{1}{145} \sin 2t, which is the particular solution that we have been seeking. Thus, our general solution agrees with what we found in .

subsection.title: Qualitative Analysis
subsection.p: We can use the complex solution of a x'' + bx' + cx = A \cos \omega t + B \sin \omega t to analyze the qualitative behavior of solutions.

example.p: We discovered that the complex solution of x'' + 6 x' + 5x = e^{2it} to be x_c = A e^{2it}, where A = (1 - 12i)/145. Let us rewrite A in polar form. Since |A| = \frac{1}{\sqrt{145}}, we know that A = \frac{1}{\sqrt{145}} e^{i \theta}, where \theta = \arctan(-12) \approx -1.4877. Therefore, x_c = A e^{2it} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{145}} e^{i \theta} e^{2it} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{145}} e^{i (2t + \theta)}. Our particular solution is the imaginary part of x_c, x_p(t) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{145}} \sin(2t + \theta) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{145}} \cos\left(2t + \theta - \frac{\pi}{2} \right) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{145} }\cos\left(2t - \phi \right), where \phi \approx 3.058451. We say that \phi is the phase anglephase angle of our solution. The amplitude of our solution is 1/\sqrt{145} and the period is \pi ().

activity.title: Finding Particular Solutions of the Form y_p = A \cos(\omega t - \phi)

introduction.p: Consider the differential equation y'' + 10 y' + 34 y = \sin 2t.

statement.p: Find the general solution to the homogeneous equation y'' + 10 y' + 34 y = 0.
Find the complex solution particular solution, y_c to y'' + 10 y' + 34 y = e^{2it}. That is, find a for y_p = a e^{2it}.
Determine A and B, so that y_p = A \cos 2t + B \sin 2t is a particular solution to
Write a from in polar form, |a| e^{i \theta} to obtain the solution y_c = |a| e^{2t + \theta}.
Find a real particular solution in the form y_p = A \cos(\omega t - \phi).
Plot the solution you found in , labeling the amplitude, period, and frequency of your solution.

subsection.p:
The corresponding first order system for the differential equation x'' + px' + qx = g(t), is
x' & = y y' & = -qx -py +g(t).
This is a nonautonomous systemnonautonomous system, and the tangent vector of a solution curve in the phase plane depends not only on the position (x, y), but also on the time t. In other words, the direction field changes with time. Since the direction field changes with time, two solutions with the same (x,y) value at different times can follow different paths. Consequently, solutions can cross each other in the xy-plane without violating the Existence and Uniqueness Theorem.

example.p:
Consider the harmonic oscillator that is modeled by the differential equation x'' + 2x' + 17x = - 2 \sin 3t. The solution to the homogeneous equation x'' + 2x' + 17x = 0 is x_h = c_1 e^{-t} \cos 4t + c_2 e^{-t} \sin 4t The complex version of this equation is x'' + 2x' + 17x = -2 e^{3it}, and we will use the Method of Undetermined Coefficients and assume that we can find a particular solution of the form x_c = A e^{3it}. Substituting x_c into equation , we find that (8 + 6i) A e^{3it} = -2 e^{3it}. Thus, x_c is a solution if A = \frac{-2}{8 + 6i} = - \frac{4}{25} + \frac{3}{25} i We have
x_c(t) & = \left(- \frac{4}{25} + \frac{3}{25} i \right) (\cos 3t + i \sin 3t) & = \left( - \frac{4}{25} \cos 3t - \frac{3}{25} \sin 3t \right) + i \left( \frac{3}{25} \cos 3t - \frac{4}{25} \sin 3t \right).
The imaginary part of this function is the solution that we seek, x_p = \frac{3}{25} \cos 3t - \frac{4}{25} \sin 3t. Thus, the general solution to is x(t) = c_1 e^{-t} \cos 4t + c_2 e^{-t} \sin 4t + \frac{3}{25} \cos 3t - \frac{4}{25} \sin 3t.

Now suppose that x(0) = 0 and x'(0) = 0. We can quickly determine that x'(t) = c_1 e^{-t}(- \cos 4t - 4 \sin 4t) + c_2 e^{-t}( 4\cos 4t - \sin 4t) - \frac{12}{25} \cos 3t - \frac{9}{25} \sin 3t To solve this initial value problem, we must solve the linear system
c_1 + \frac{3}{25} \amp = 0 - c_1 + 4 c_2 - \frac{12}{25} \amp = 0.
We obtain c_1 = -3/25 and c_2 = 9/100, and the solution to our initial value problem is
x(t) & = -\frac{3}{25} e^{-t}(- \cos 4t - 4 \sin 4t) + \frac{3}{20} e^{-t}( 4\cos 4t - \sin 4t) - \frac{12}{25} \cos 3t - \frac{9}{25} \sin 3t & = -\frac{3}{100} (4 \cos 4t - 3 \sin 4t)) e^{-t} - \frac{12}{25} \cos 3t - \frac{9}{25} \sin 3t
The graph of our solution is given in .

example.p: Since y = x'(t), we can now graph the solution curve in the phase plane (). Notice how the solution curve can intersect itself. The restoring force and damping are proportional to x and y = x', respectively. When x and y are close to the origin, the external force is as large or larger than the restoring and damping forces. In this part of the xy-plane, the external force overcomes the damping and pushes the solution away from the origin.

example.p:
On the other hand, suppose we have initial conditions x(0) = 2 and x'(0) = 2, we can solve the linear system
c_1 + \frac{3}{25} \amp = 2 -4 c_1 - c_2 - \frac{9}{25} \amp = 2.
to obtain c_1 = 47/25 and c_2 = 109/100. Thus, solution to our initial value problem is x(t) = \frac{47}{25} e^{-t} \cos 4t + \frac{109}{100} e^{-t} \sin 4t + \frac{3}{40} \cos 2t - \frac{3}{20} \sin 2t. The graph of our solution is given in .

example.p: If we examine the phase plane for this solution (), we see that the initial damping and restoring forces are much larger than the external force. Thus, if we are far from the origin, the solutions in the xy-plane tend to spiral towards the origin and are similar to the solutions of the unforced equation.

ul.li: The functions \sin \omega t and g(t) = \cos \omega t are periodic with period 2 \pi / \omega and frequency \omega / 2 \pi. These average value of each of these functions is zero.

We can use Euler's formula and complexification to solve the equation x'' + px' + qx = g(t), where the forcing function g(t) is \sin \omega t or \cos \omega t. Furthermore, we can use complex numbers to express or solution in the form x(t) = A \cos(\omega t - \phi), where A is the amplitude of the solution, \omega / 2 \pi is the frequency of the solution, and \phi is the phase angle.

If we write the equation x'' + px' + qx = g(t), as a first-order system,
x' & = y y' & = -qx -py +g(t),
we obtain a nonautonomous system. In this case the direction field changes with time, and two solutions with the same (x,y) value at different times can follow different paths. Therefore, solutions can cross each other without violating the Existence and Uniqueness Theorem.

If we are far from the origin, the solutions in the xy-plane tend to spiral towards the origin and are similar to the solutions of the unforced equation. When x and y are close to the origin, the external force is as large or larger than the restoring and damping forces. In this part of the xy-plane, the external force overcomes the damping and pushes the solution away from the origin.

exercise.p: Is it possible for solution curves to intersect in the phase plane of a nonautonomous system? Why or why not?
